content.raw: I pulled this branch into the osrf repository
content.html: I pulled this branch into the osrf repository

content.raw: Sounds good
content.html: Sounds good

content.raw:
I agree with the transport library concerns. In this situation sensor and physics run in the same process, and as far as I can tell this is currently fast and reliable. The data needed by a sensor is also sporadic, except for time.

A model and world plugin can get a pointer to a sensor using `sensors::get_sensor()`. As long a the plugin links against the sensor library, and doesn't behave improperly, everything should be fine.
content.html:
I agree with the transport library concerns. In this situation sensor and physics run in the same process, and as far as I can tell this is currently fast and reliable. The data needed by a sensor is also sporadic, except for time.

A model and world plugin can get a pointer to a sensor using sensors::get_sensor(). As long a the plugin links against the sensor library, and doesn't behave improperly, everything should be fine.

content.raw:
I think there's some degree of trade-off between the two

* transport can be unreliable (at least the current gazebo transport) and may be delayed
* c++ API access has issues with linking and thread concurrency
content.html:
I think there's some degree of trade-off between the two

  • transport can be unreliable (at least the current gazebo transport) and may be delayed
  • c++ API access has issues with linking and thread concurrency

content.raw: That is the direction I've been working toward. Right now this approach works well. No extra information is published by links because things like gravity are already published.
content.html: That is the direction I've been working toward. Right now this approach works well. No extra information is published by links because things like gravity are already published.

content.raw: How will the [ImuSensor get access to gravity data](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/097fae5d041c79096f2f8fa2650acf119ae908f5/gazebo/sensors/ImuSensor.cc#ImuSensor.cc-419) then? Will the parent link have to publish everything that its sensor needs?
content.html: How will the ImuSensor get access to gravity data then? Will the parent link have to publish everything that its sensor needs?

content.raw: We are removing the dependency between sensors and the physics library. This means the sensor library will not have direct access to physics properties, and function like `GetWorldPtr` in the sensor library will not be possible.
content.html: We are removing the dependency between sensors and the physics library. This means the sensor library will not have direct access to physics properties, and function like GetWorldPtr in the sensor library will not be possible.

content.raw: The imu noise model has also been implemented.
content.html: The imu noise model has also been implemented.

content.raw: For reference, the altimeter and magnetometer have been merged into Gazebo.
content.html: For reference, the altimeter and magnetometer have been merged into Gazebo.

content.html:

  • https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issues/1667/should-altimetersensor-output-depend-on

content.html: Set the magnetic field measurement

content.raw: Apply magnetometer noise after converting to body frame
content.html: Apply magnetometer noise after converting to body frame

content.raw:
This assumes gravity acts in the negative Z direction, which is the default. I wonder if there is a benefit to making it more general by defining the "vertical direction" based on the gravity vector. If the gravity vector has zero length, should the altimeter output anything?

For the first implementation, I think we should ignore these questions, but they might be worth considering in case people prefer using a different vertical axis.
content.html:
This assumes gravity acts in the negative Z direction, which is the default. I wonder if there is a benefit to making it more general by defining the "vertical direction" based on the gravity vector. If the gravity vector has zero length, should the altimeter output anything?

For the first implementation, I think we should ignore these questions, but they might be worth considering in case people prefer using a different vertical axis.

content.raw: TFor
content.html: TFor

update.description:
I have created these design documents in response to the meeting at the OSRF on June 22, 2015. 

This pull request introduces the following new ideas:

1. A new altimeter sensor that makes use of the generic noise model architecture
1. A new magnetometer sensor that make use of generic noise model architecture
1. An update to the IMU sensor that moves it to the generic noise architecture
1. A proposal to add clock noise, which would optionally perturb sensor measurement timestamps to mimic  the effect of clocks that drift with respect to each other.
1. A modification to the NoiseFactory class to take a reference to a sensor, with the goal of giving noise models the ability to measure pose/twist/time. 
1. The introduction of an Ornstein-Uhlenbeck time-correlated noise model
1. The introduction of an Wiener time-correlated noise model
update.title: Improve sensor noise models

update.description:
I have created these design documents in response to yesterday's meeting at the OSRF. This pull request introduces the following:

1. A new altimeter sensor that makes use of the generic noise model architecture
1. A new magnetometer sensor that make use of generic noise model architecture
1. An update to the IMU sensor that moves it to the generic noise architecture
1. A proposal to add clock noise, which would optionally perturb sensor measurement timestamps to mimic  the effect of clocks that drift with respect to each other.
1. A modification to the NoiseFactory class to take a reference to a sensor, with the goal of giving noise models the ability to measure pose/twist/time. 
1. The introduction of an Ornstein-Uhlenbeck time-correlated noise model
1. The introduction of an Wiener time-correlated noise model

update.description: I have created these design documents in response to yesterday's meeting at the OSRF. This pull request introduces new altimeter and magnetometer sensors that make use of generic noise models, and an update to the IMU sensor that moves it to the generic noise architecture. There is also a proposal to add clock noise, which would optionally perturb sensor measurement timestamps to mimic  the effect of clocks that drift with respect to each other.
update.title: Improve sensor noise models

This pull request introduces new altimeter and magnetometer sensors that make use of generic noise models, and an update to the IMU sensor that moves it to the generic noise architecture. There is also a proposal to add clock noise, which would optionally perturb sensor measurement timestamps to mimic  the effect of clocks that drift with respect to each other.

content.raw: The only reason I proposed it this way is because I didn't want the clock bound to a single sensor. This is because in many cases (as with an IMU/magnetometer combo) the same microcontroller clock is used to time stamp both sensor measurements. However, two different robots have two different clocks, each of which timestamps the IMU/mag measurements respectively.
content.html: The only reason I proposed it this way is because I didn't want the clock bound to a single sensor. This is because in many cases (as with an IMU/magnetometer combo) the same microcontroller clock is used to time stamp both sensor measurements. However, two different robots have two different clocks, each of which timestamps the IMU/mag measurements respectively.

content.raw: In intended the clock noise model to use it. The idea being that temperature is one of the biggest factors that affects clock drift. Temperature also happens to be spatially-correlated, and so it may be important at some stage to know where the clock / oscillator is in the world.
content.html: In intended the clock noise model to use it. The idea being that temperature is one of the biggest factors that affects clock drift. Temperature also happens to be spatially-correlated, and so it may be important at some stage to know where the clock / oscillator is in the world.

content.raw:
This document has the biggest architectural questions in my opinion.

It's interesting for `Clock`'s to be owned by `Link`'s. I'll think about this some more
content.html:
This document has the biggest architectural questions in my opinion.

It's interesting for Clock's to be owned by Link's. I'll think about this some more

content.raw: This is an interesting point. I initially added the `Noise` class to `gazebo::sensors`, but it could conceivably be in a lower-level class.
content.html: This is an interesting point. I initially added the Noise class to gazebo::sensors, but it could conceivably be in a lower-level class.

content.raw: Out of curiosity; how is the `pose` of the clock used?
content.html: Out of curiosity; how is the pose of the clock used?
